title: How to Make Corn Tortillas

steps.headline: Stir the masa and water in a large bowl.
steps.description: Pour the 2 cups (228 g) into the bowl. Then, in increments, add the 1.125 cups (266 mL) and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of water. This'll help make the dough nice and even. Use a spoon to gently mix the ingredients.

steps.headline: Knead the ingredients until it turns into a smooth dough.
steps.description: Use your hands to press, stretch, and fold the dough. If your dough is too wet or starchy, consider adding a bit more masa or water. The dough should be smooth, not sticky. You should be able to form small dough balls easily in your hands, almost like Play-Doh.

steps.headline: Let the dough sit for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the bowl with a towel and let it sit on your counter to give the masa time to fully absorb the water. This helps improve the taste and texture of your tortillas.

steps.headline: Break the dough into 12 small balls with your hands.
steps.description: For extra precision, scoop the dough with a tablespoon scoop. The balls will be relatively small. If you want bigger tortillas, make fewer dough balls. Do the reverse if you want smaller tortillas.

steps.headline: Place a dough ball in between 2 pieces of wax paper.
steps.description: Press down on the dough slightly to make rolling it easier. Wax paper is perfect because it won’t stick to and ruin the dough. If you don’t have wax paper, use parchment paper instead.

steps.headline: Roll the dough into flat circles with a rolling pin.
steps.description: Each circle should be approximately 6 inches (15 cm) in diameter and 0.125 inches (0.32 cm) thick. If the dough tears, just use your hands to roll it back into a ball and roll it out again. You can use a tortilla press instead of a rolling pin. The tortillas should be pretty thin, but you can make them thicker or thinner depending on your preference. It’s ok if your tortillas aren’t perfectly round.

steps.headline: Stack your tortillas with wax paper.
steps.description: In between each tortilla, lay down a piece of wax paper. Keep them stacked until you are ready to cook them. The wax paper helps keep your tortillas intact by making sure they don’t stick to each other.

steps.headline: Heat a nonstick skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Try to use a cast-iron pan because they distribute the flame’s heat quickly and evenly. To test if the skillet is hot enough, drop some water on it. If it sizzles immediately, then you can start cooking the tortillas. You can also use a griddle. If you don’t have a nonstick cooking option, then brush both sides of each tortilla with a small amount of vegetable oil. This prevents the metal from sticking.

steps.headline: Put a tortilla in the skillet and cook the first side for 30 to 60 seconds.
steps.description: Unless you're using a griddle with lots of space, you'll need to heat the tortillas 1 at a time. By the 1 minute mark, your tortilla’s surface should look dry and mostly firm.

steps.headline: Flip the tortilla with a spatula and let it cook for up to 1 minute.
steps.description: Carefully and slowly use a spatula to flip over the tortilla. Do this once the edges on the tortilla start to curl up. Once you flip it, you can tell that your tortilla is done cooking if both sides have brown spots on them. If you want a charred tortilla, you can cook the tortilla for 90 seconds on 1 side. Then, flip the tortilla over and let it cook for only 15 seconds.

steps.headline: Wrap your cooked tortillas in a towel.
steps.description: Stack them and wrap them in a clean towel. This helps keep the tortillas moist and steamy. Once you’ve wrapped them up, they’re ready to be eaten! You can also use a styrofoam tortilla keeper to keep your tortillas warm.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the tortillas if you want to save them.
steps.description: While corn tortillas are best served hot, you can refrigerate them to save them for later. To store them, keep the tortillas wrapped in a towel and put them in an airtight container or ziplock bag in the fridge. They’ll stay good for up to 3 days. Let the tortillas cool completely before putting them in the fridge.
